title: Color palettes
text: following vignettes provide overview examples using unicol color palettes:

title: Using color palettes
text: Task: Using unicol colors visualizations created base R graphics. unicol color palettes typically provided named vectors color objects. Thus, creating base R visualizations (e.g., using plot() creating scatterplot), can directly use color palette col argument. instance, let’s assume wanted create bar chart using color palette uni_bonn_2 (University Bonn, Germany):  can simply provide color palette col argument barplot() function:  case want modify color palette (e.g., change number colors add transparency) using , can using usecol() function unikn package providing modified palette col argument R graphics function. following examples illustrate alternatives.  Directly using color palette (e.g., color palette caltech_1):  Using transformed color palette (using usecol() function unikn package resizing adding transparency palette):
code: # View color palette: unikn::seecol(uni_bonn_2, main = "Color gradient of the University of Bonn, Germany") # Use a color palette: barplot(1/sqrt(1:10), col = uni_bonn_2) # View color palette: unikn::seecol(caltech_1, main = "The colors of Caltech, USA") plot(x = runif(99), y = runif(99), type = "p",       pch = 16, cex = 4,      col = caltech_1,      main = "99 dots (in Caltech colors)", axes = FALSE, xlab = NA, ylab = NA) my_col <- unikn::usecol(caltech_1, alpha = .60)  # with transparency  plot(x = runif(99), y = runif(99), type = "p",       pch = 16, cex = 4,      col = my_col,      main = "99 transparent dots", axes = FALSE, xlab = NA, ylab = NA)

title: Using color palettes
text: Task: Using unicol colors visualizations created ggplot2 package. using ggplot() function ggplot2 (e.g., creating area plot), wrap color palette usecol() function (unikn package) defining color palette (desired length transparency). resulting color palette can provided values ggplot2’s scale_color_manual() scale_fill_manual() functions: Wrap desired color palette usecol() function unikn. Provide palette values ggplot2 functions scale_color_manual() scale_fill_manual().
code: # 0. Create some data to plot: ----   # Example based on https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/137-spring-shapes-data-art/ n <- 50 groups <- 1:n df <- data.frame()  set.seed(3)  for (i in seq(1:30)){   data = data.frame(matrix(0, n, 3))   data[, 1] <- i   data[, 2] <- sample(groups, nrow(data))   data[, 3] <- prop.table(sample(c(rep(0, 100), c(1:n)), nrow(data)))   df = rbind(df, data)}  names(df) <- c("X","Group","Y") df$Group <- as.factor(df$Group)   df <- df[c(2, 1, 3)] df <- df[order(df$X, df$Group) , ] rownames(df) <- NULL  my_data <- df  # # View data (as wider table): # my_data_wider <- tidyr::pivot_wider(my_data, names_from = Group, names_prefix = "g_", values_from = Y) # knitr::kable(my_data_wider, caption = "Viewing data (in wider format).")   # 1. Colors: ----   # A. Using RColorBrewer:  # library(RColorBrewer)  # my_pal <- brewer.pal(11, "Paired") # my_pal <- colorRampPalette(my_pal)(n) # my_pal <- my_pal[sample(c(1:length(my_pal)), size = length(my_pal))]  # randomize  # B. Using unicol colors: library(unicol)  # Mix a color gradient:  my_pal <- unikn::usecol(princeton_1, n = 50) # my_pal <- my_pal[sample(c(1:length(my_pal)), size = length(my_pal))]  # randomize   # 2. Plotting (with ggplot2): ----   library(ggplot2)  ggplot2::ggplot(my_data, aes(x = X, y = Y, fill = Group)) +    geom_area() +   scale_fill_manual(values = my_pal) +   theme_void() +   theme(legend.position = "none")

title: The Colors of your University
text: unicol package provides colors color palettes, whereas unikn package provides color-related functions:
code: library(unicol)  # for color palettes library(unikn)   # for color functions

title: The Colors of your University
text: unicol package currently provides 202 color palettes 86 institutions. (See vignette Color palettes overview color palettes institutions.)

title: The Colors of your University
text: Figure 1 illustrates 50 random color palettes (251 colors): Figure 1: sample 50 unicol palettes (containing 251 colors).

title: The Colors of your University
text: unicol palettes provided vectors R colors, can simply used col argument R graphics functions. instance, can use MIT colors (Massachusetts Institute Technology) bar plot (barplot() function base R graphics package) follows:  modify color palette (e.g., resizing palette adding transparency), use usecol() function unikn package:  additional examples color palettes unicol can used:
code: barplot(height = 1:10,         col = mit_pal,          main = "Using the MIT colors") barplot(height = 1/sqrt(1:16),          col = usecol(mit_pal, n = 16),          main = "A color gradient of MIT colors") # Viewing a color palette: unikn::seecol(yale_1, main = "The primary colors of Yale University") # Demo plots: unikn::demopal(berkeley_1, type = 2, main = "The colors of Berkeley, University of California", seed = 3) unikn::demopal(limerick_1, type = 3, main = "Using the colors of the University of Limerick", seed = 3)

title: Core colors of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), USA — CMU_1_core
text: core colors Carnegie Mellon University, registered since late 1920s, "carnegie_red" (defined CMYK 0/100/79/20, RGB R196/18/48, HEX #C41230), "iron_gray" (defined CMYK 0/0/0/70, RGB R109/110/113, HEX #6D6E71), "steel_gray" (defined CMYK 0/0/0/30, RGB R224/224/224, HEX #E0E0E0), "black" (defined CMYK 0/0/0/100, RGB R0/0/0, HEX #000000), "white". CMU_1_core uses HEX color definitions. Carnegie red dominant color color scheme. grays, black white support Carnegie red. Official university collateral, uniforms, vehicles, signs key identity elements always produced using core color palette.

title: Core colors of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), USA — CMU_1_core
Core colors of Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), USA — CMU_1_core
code: CMU_1_core #> carnegie_red    iron_gray   steel_gray        black        white  #>    "#C41230"    "#6D6E71"    "#E0E0E0"    "#000000"    "#FFFFFF"  unikn::seecol(CMU_1_core, main = "Core colors CMU") # view color palette

text: Named colors uni_regensburg_1 correspond following UR services: neutralgrau: Main color (UR-Hausfarbe, Logo) blaugrau: Leitung, Organe und Verwaltung (LOV, Ausnahme: Referate /3, /4, /5, /6) schwarzrot: Chancengleichheit und Familie (Familien-Service, Frauenbeauftragte, Frauenfoerderung, Gleichstellung) schilfgruen: Service-Einrichtungen der Verwaltung für Studierende (Akademisches Auslandsamt, Studentenkanzlei, Zentrales Pruefungssekretariat, Zentrale Studienberatung, Senatsbeauftragter für Behinderte und chronisch Kranke) dianthusrot: Universitaetsbibliothek (UB) saphirblau: Rechenzentrum (RZ) farngruen: Zentrum fuer Weiterbildung rotbraun: Zentrum fuer Sprache und Kommunikation (ZSK) perlviolett: Europaeum (Ost-West-Zentrum) violettrot: Zentrum fuer Hochschul- und Wissenschaftsdidaktik (ZHW) gruenbraun: Regensburger Universitätszentrum fuer Lehrerbildung (RUL) wasserblau: Sportzentrum (SZ) coloring large areas, named colors may used shades 70
